profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-06-09T14:52-0400
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid content adheres to that prescribed by Describing Archives: A Content Standard.

did.abstract: Richard Halliburton traveled extensively in the first part of twentieth century after graduating from Princeton University in 1921. The collection contains autograph and typescript drafts of seven of Halliburton's books, short stories, essays, school notes, and other travel memorabilia, as well as Halliburton's correspondence with his parents and others, research materials about Rupert Brooke, and a significant group of photographs documenting his travels throughout Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Middle East.
did.physloc: This collection is stored partially onsite at Firestone Library and partially offsite at the ReCAP facility (Boxes 35-39). Boxes 46-52 are stored in glass plate storage.

bioghist.p: Richard Halliburton was an American traveler, adventurer, and author, whose books about his exploits captured the romantic spirit of his generation. He followed Ulysses' route through the Mediterranean and emulated Lord Byron by swimming the Hellespont. He swam the Panama Canal, ran from Marathon to Athens, visited the penal colony at Devil's Island, and climbed the Matterhorn, Mount Olympus, and Mount Fuji. These and other experiences became the basis for Halliburton's romantic narratives; and his literary career developed out of his meticulous logging of events that occurred on his adventures. However, in March 1939, Halliburton left Hong Kong aboard a motor-powered Chinese junk called the "Sea Dragon", which he had built, en route to San Francisco. Both he and his boat disappeared after encountering a severe typhoon, some 1,200 miles west of Midway Island.

scopecontent.p: The papers span Halliburton's short but adventurous life, from his Lawrenceville School essay, "Disillusioned," through his Princeton University years (Princeton Class of 1921), his years of worldwide travel, lecturing, and writing, to his posthumously-published "autobiography" of letters to his parents (1940). Autograph and/or typescript drafts of seven of his books, The Royal Road to Romance (1925), The Glorious Adventure (1927), New Worlds to Conquer (1929), The Flying Carpet (1932), Seven League Boots (1935), A Book of Marvels (1937), and Second Book of Marvels (1938), are present, as are some short stories, essays, and notes from his school days. There are also passports, publishing contracts, memorabilia, maps, and newspapers clippings. Halliburton's numerous letters to his parents (1919-1939) provide a vivid account of his travels, and they are supplemented by a large quanitity of photographic prints and negatives documenting the locations he visited, many of which were never published in his books. Correspondence of others includes letters from Devil's Island prisoners, with some manuscripts. Also present are Halliburton's research materials for a biography of Rupert Brooke that he never wrote, including his correspondence with Brooke's friends and acquaintances and summaries of interviews he had with them, as well as copies of Brooke's works and correspondence, some clippings, and photographs.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following five series: Works; Correspondence; Biographical Materials; Photographs; and Papers of Others.

accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research use.

Original film-based photographic negatives (Boxes 35-39) are stored offsite in cold storage at the ReCAP facility. Please consult with the Special Collections about having this portion of the collection recalled to Firestone Library for your use. This process normally requires 48-72 hours notice.

userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Inquiries regarding publishing material from the collection should be directed to RBSC Public Services staff at rbsc@princeton.edu.

Copyright and literary rights for materials created by Richard Halliburton in this collection are held by the Trustees of Princeton University. The 78 letters and 5 telegrams by Halliburton to Lawrance Chambers, his editor at Bobbs-Merrill, require permission from Louis de Rochemont if they are to be used for movie or TV productions.

acqinfo.p: Papers of Halliburton are a gift of Wesley Halliburton. Collection of letters and telegrams from Halliburton to his editor is a gift of Thomas Orchard. Photographs are a gift of William C. Wilson. Misc. manuscripts, documents, correspondence are a gift of the First National Bank of Memphis. 3 Letters from Halliburton to P.L. Williams were purchased in 2005. An inscribed copy of The Royal Road to Romance was a gift of Patricia A. Oakes in 2017.

altformavail.p: Publications: All of Halliburton's books were published by Bobbs-Merrill of Indianapolis: The Royal Road to Romance (1925), The Glorious Adventure (1927), New Worlds to Conquer (1929), The Flying Carpet (1932), Seven League Boots (1935), A Book of Marvels (1937), Second Book of Marvels (1938), Richard Halliburton: His Story of His Life's Adventures (1940).

prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Richard Halliburton Papers, Box and Folder Number; Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

processinfo.p: Finding aid updated and all photographic materials rehoused by Kelly Bolding in 2016, with assistance from Fiona Bell '18.

arrangement.p: Arranged into three subseries by genre.

scopecontent.p: This series contains writings by Richard Halliburton, including books, such as Complete Book of Marvels and The Flying Carpet, articles and short works, such as "The Elephants and the Alps" and "Experiments in Assination," and some early works.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title of work.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains drafts and related materials for Richard Halliburton's published books. Photographs from Halliburton's travels documented in his books can be found in Series 4: Photographs.

unittitle.emph: Richard Halliburton: His Story of His Life's Adventures

did.unittitle: The Royal Road to Romance Inscribed Copy

scopecontent.p: Hardback copy of The Royal Road to Romance (Bobbs-Merrill Company, 1925), inscribed by Richard Halliburton on February 17, 1926, to Miss Clara Engel on a photograph of Halliburton in Athens, which is affixed to the title page. A two-page letter from Halliburton to Engels, written on Hotel Bristol (New York) stationary, is pasted in at the end of the book.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of personal documents, clippings of articles and other printed materials about Halliburton's life and travels, and various memorabilia he kept, such as event programs, clippings, maps, and artwork.

scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of writings and clippings about Richard Halliburton's travels, including an announcement for his election to Associate Editor of The Lawrence, a Vanity Fair article titled "We nominate For Oblivion: R.H.," as well as other printed materials regarding Richard Halliburton.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains various memorabilia kept by Richard Halliburton, including Class Day and graduation programs from Princeton University, clippings, and other printed materials, as well as a collection of maps and tourist guides documenting locations Halliburton visited, some artwork he collected, and miscellaneous notes and addresses.

did.unittitle: Dryburgh Abbey: Its Monks and Its Lords

His Name was Mudd, George Allan England

scopecontent.p: Includes materials, titled "Tunisie," "Bali," "Vierwaldstattersee," "Deutschland, Oesterreich, der Schweiz and angrenzenden Landern," "Switzerland," "Rheinlauf," "Short Guide to Bali," largely geared towards tourists.

Original folder also marked "Story of Richard's Com. Appeal." Includes National Geographic maps titled "Europe and the Near East," "Pacific Ocean and the Bay of Bengal," "Southeast Asia and Pacific Islands from the Indies and the Philippines to the Solomons," "Germany and Its Approaches," "The World," "Bible Lands and the Cradle of Western Civilization," "The United States of America," "Countries of the Caribbean Including Mexico," "Central America and the West Indies," and "Japan and Korea."

Includes maps titled "The Countries of the Caribbean including Mexico, Central America, the West Indies and the Panama Canal," "A Plan of the City, and Lake of Mexico" (annotated), "West Indies," "Cuba, Jamaica, and the Bahama Islands," "Panama" (annotated), and a large 5 x 3 foot linen-mounted map titled "Mapa de la Republica de Panama," which contains annotations regarding Halliburton's travels through Panama and the Panama Canal.

Consists of several large, rolled artworks, including a drawing of "La Cite de Carcassonne," photographs of Mount Olympus and the Parthenon, and other materials.

This series consists of a significant group of photographic materials extensively documenting Halliburton's international travels in the Americas, Europe, Asia, and Africa, including journeys described in his published books, and to a lesser extent his friends at Princeton and his home. Black-and-white photographic prints, nitrate and acetate negatives, glass show slides, and glass plate negatives are all present. While photographic materials have been physically stored by type for preservation purposes, they are listed by subject in the finding aid.

scopecontent.p: This subseries includes photographic materials related to Halliburton's personal life and other travels, including portraits of Halliburton, portraits of his Princeton University friends, and photographs of his Hangover House residence, his boat the Sea Dragon, and other subjects. Also present are his show slides (glass lantern slides) which document his travels and which he likely used in giving public talks about his adventures.
6 photographs.
Includes one severely damaged acetate negative. Duplicate.

did.unittitle: Sea Dragon, Photograph by Robert Pullen

scopecontent.p: Oversize photographic print and and digital copy of Richard Halliburton's junk Sea Dragon before its fatal sail, taken by Robert Pullen. Copy of contemporary portrait of Pullen is included.
Includes 19 black-and-white photographs, primarily of the dam under construction, and a tourist guide titled "View-Book of the Boulder Dam."

Contains approximately 40 leaves of a scrapbook (unbound) with photographs partially pasted on each page (sometimes on both sides of the page) taken during Halliburton's worldwide travels. Also includes one mounted photo of Dahl Lake in Kashmir.

did.unittitle: John the Baptist, Glass Plate Negatives

unittitle.altrender: Man with the Golden Helmet Print

did.unittitle: "The Man with the Golden Helmet" Print

scopecontent.p: Includes 141 numbered and 28 unnumbered glass lantern slides that are positive and in color. Numbered slides were removed from their original carrying case and sleeves were numbered to indicate their original order. Unnumbered slides were found loose. The numbered slides seem to be arranged in order of display and are apparently Halliburton's show slides. 4 broken slides (housed in Box 51) were encapsulated in archival plexiglass to facilitate handling.

did.unittitle: Glass Plate and Film Negative Packaging

scopecontent.p: This series consists of papers of others collected by Richard Halliburton, including papers of Rupert Brooke and Wesley Halliburton, and papers regarding John Wilkes Booth and Richmond Pearson Hobson.
Consists of the papers of Rupert Brooke, including his works, correspondence, memorabilia, clippings, and photographs.
